Shock comes, going and coming. Danger. Nonetheless, you lose nothing. But there are things to do. The shock oscillates, comes and goes. Danger remains. Yet you lose nothing essential. There are things to do—attend to them. The shock is now background, not foreground.

Shock brings ruin and terrified gazing. Setting forth brings misfortune. If the shock has not reached you but your neighbor, there is no blame. Your companions have something to talk about. The worst shock: ruin, paralysis. To set forth now brings misfortune. But if the shock spares you and strikes your neighbor, there is no blame. Grieve with them, help them, but do not take their shock as your own.

trigrams.description: Thunder over thunder. Shock upon shock. This is the moment of crisis multiplied, the event that shakes the world twice. The wise one does not deny the shock; they meet it with presence, knowing that thunder passes and stillness remains.

taoist_reflection: The Tao Te Ching says: 'If you realize that all things change, there is nothing you will try to hold on to.' Hexagram 51 is the teaching of impermanence made violent. Thunder comes, thunder goes. The sacred wine does not spill—not because the hand is rigid, but because it is so present that even shock cannot disrupt it. The sage, like the hand that holds the ladle, is not shaken because they are not attached. Let the thunder roll. You are already home.

name: Keeping Still (艮 - Gèn)
heart: Mountain over mountain. Stillness upon stillness. The mountain does not move; it simply rests. Keeping Still is the art of stopping—not as avoidance, but as completion. When the spine is still, the body rests. When the mind is still, the world settles. The sage knows when to stop: at the right moment, in the right place, with no regret.

ancient.chinese: 艮其背，不獲其身，行其庭，不見其人。无咎。
ancient.rendering: Keeping Still. Keeping his back still, he is no longer aware of his body. Walking in his courtyard, he does not see his neighbors. No blame.

judgment: To keep the back still is to let the world go. When the spine is still, the body is forgotten. When the self is forgotten, others are not objects of grasping. Walking in the courtyard, you do not see your neighbors—not because you reject them, but because you are not seeking. No blame attends this stillness. It is the ground of all right action. From stillness, when you do move, you move truly.
image: Mountains standing together. The noble one does not let his thoughts go beyond his situation. Mountains together: they rest, they endure. The noble one learns: do not let thoughts go beyond your situation. Be fully here, in this moment, with what is. Thoughts that wander are like streams that leave the mountain; they do not return. Keep your mind on what is present, and you will not be scattered.
lines: Keeping his toes still. No blame. Perseverance furthers. The toes—the beginning of movement. To still them before they move is wise. No blame because you have not yet taken a wrong step. Persevere in this early stillness, and it will further all that follows.

Keeping his calves still. He cannot rescue him whom he follows. His heart is not glad. The calves move with the legs; they are not independent. If you still them after movement has begun, you cannot rescue the one you follow—your own impulse. The heart is not glad because the timing is off. Better to still earlier, or not at all.

Keeping his hips still. Makes his ribs rigid. Danger. The heart suffocates. To still the hips—the center of movement—after you are already in motion makes the whole body rigid. The ribs lock; the heart cannot breathe. Danger because you are fighting yourself. If you must still, still at the source, not in mid-motion.

Keeping his trunk still. No blame. The trunk—the core, the center. To still the center is to find balance. No blame because you are not preventing movement; you are grounding it. From this still center, all movement can arise cleanly.

Keeping his jaws still. Words have order. Regret disappears. The jaws—speech. To still them is to speak only when words are true and ordered. Regret disappears because you do not speak in haste. The stillness of the jaws is not silence; it is the pause before right speech.

Keeping his back still. Good fortune. The culmination: the back, the spine, the deepest support. To keep the back still is to be so grounded that the body is forgotten. Good fortune because you are no longer reacting to the world; you are simply present, and from that presence, all action is true.

trigrams.description: Mountain over mountain. Stillness upon stillness. This is the meditation of form: each mountain rests, each moment completes. The wise one learns that true stillness is not a void; it is the full presence of what is, unmoving and complete.

taoist_reflection: The Tao Te Ching says: 'Do you have the patience to wait till your mud settles and the water is clear? Can you remain unmoving till the right action arises by itself?' Hexagram 52 is the answer: yes. Keeping still is not passivity; it is the deepest activity. The mountain does not move, yet all things grow around it. The sage does not strive, yet all things are accomplished. In stillness, the mud settles, the water clears, and right action arises of itself.

name: Development (漸 - Jiàn)
heart: Wind over mountain. The wind moves slowly, shaping the mountain over eons. Development is gradual progress—not a leap, but a steady ascent. The wild goose flies step by step, from shore to shore, never rushing, never stopping. In human life, true growth is like this: patient, persistent, inevitable. Do not force; just continue.

ancient.chinese: 漸。女歸吉，利貞。
ancient.rendering: Development. The maiden is given in marriage. Good fortune. Perseverance furthers.

judgment: The wild goose flies from shore to shore, each step measured, each resting place earned. Development is not a leap but a pilgrimage. The maiden goes to her new home not in haste but in trust, knowing that what is built slowly endures. Perseverance in this gradual approach brings good fortune because you are not skipping the steps that make the destination meaningful. Do not despise the slow days; they are the ones that carry you farthest.
image: Wind over mountain. The noble one abides in clarity and moves with patience. Wind over mountain: it shapes the stone not by force but by persistence. The noble one learns: abide in clarity—know where you are going. Move with patience—accept that the journey takes time. The mountain does not resent the wind's slow work; it becomes a masterpiece of erosion. Your character, too, is being shaped by forces you cannot see. Trust the process.
lines: The wild goose gradually draws near the shore. The young son is in danger. There is talk. No blame. First step: approach the shore. There is danger—the son is young, inexperienced. There is talk—gossip, concern. But no blame because the movement is natural. Continue.

The wild goose gradually draws near the cliff. Eating and drinking in peace and concord. Good fortune. Second step: the cliff, a resting place. Eating and drinking in peace—replenishment. Good fortune because you take time to gather strength. Do not rush past the resting places.

The wild goose gradually draws near the plateau. The husband goes forth and does not return. The wife is pregnant but does not give birth. Misfortune. You might take robbers for a good cause. Third step: the plateau, exposed. The husband leaves and does not return—separation. The wife is pregnant but does not give birth—potential unfulfilled. Misfortune because the timing is off. You may mistake robbers for good people—trust the wrong thing. Pause and reassess.

The wild goose gradually draws near the tree. It may light on a branch. No blame. Fourth step: the tree, a higher perch. It may light on a branch—not the top, not the bottom, just a place to rest. No blame because it is enough for now. Development does not demand the peak at every stage.

The wild goose gradually draws near the summit. For three years the wife has no child. In the end nothing can oppose her. Good fortune. Fifth step: near the summit. For three years, no child—long patience, no visible result. But in the end, nothing can oppose her. Good fortune because perseverance has built a momentum that cannot be stopped.

The wild goose gradually draws near the cloud heights. Its feathers can be used for the sacred dance. Good fortune. Final step: the cloud heights, the highest stage. The feathers—what was once just for flight—are now sacred, used in the dance. Good fortune because development has transformed the ordinary into the holy. The journey itself becomes the offering.

trigrams.description: Wind over mountain. The wind shapes the mountain slowly, grain by grain. Development is this patient transformation: not a flood, but a steady breeze. The mountain does not resist; it yields over time. The wise one learns that true change is gradual, and that which endures is built slowly.

taoist_reflection: The Tao Te Ching says: 'The journey of a thousand miles begins under your feet.' Hexagram 53 is the journey itself, step by step, day by day. The wild goose does not leap to the clouds; it flies from shore to shore, resting when needed, pressing on when ready. The sage does not seek enlightenment in a flash; they cultivate it slowly, patiently, with the certainty of water wearing down stone. In the end, the feathers become sacred—not because they were special, but because they were faithful.

name: The Marrying Maiden (歸妹 - Guī Mèi)
heart: Thunder over lake. Thunder stirs, the lake responds—but the union is not equal. The marrying maiden is a secondary wife, entering a household not as the principal but as a supplement. Her position is precarious; her influence, limited. This hexagram speaks of relationships entered without full commitment, of unions that serve a purpose but lack depth. The wise one in such a situation does not demand what cannot be given; they accept the limits and make the best of what is.

ancient.chinese: 歸妹。征凶，无攸利。
ancient.rendering: The Marrying Maiden. To undertake something brings misfortune. Nothing that would further.

judgment: This is not a time for great undertakings. The position is secondary, the power limited. To push for more, to demand equality where it is not offered, brings misfortune. Nothing furthers because the foundation is not solid. Yet the maiden can still find her way: by accepting her place with grace, by fulfilling her role with sincerity, she may earn a deeper regard. But do not mistake this hexagram for a call to action. It is a call to patience, to clarity about what is possible, and to dignity within constraint.
lines: The marrying maiden as a concubine. A lame man can still tread. Setting forth brings good fortune. The lowest position, the least status. Yet like a lame man who can still walk, she can still move, still act. Setting forth—within her limits—brings good fortune. Do what you can with what you have.

A one-eyed man can still see. The perseverance of a solitary man furthers. Limited vision, but not blindness. The solitary man—one without allies—can still persevere. In a secondary position, you may see less, have less support, but you can still see truly. Persevere in that seeing.

The marrying maiden waits. She returns as a concubine. The waiting is not passive; it is preparation. She returns—not to the same place, but to a similar role. The line does not judge; it describes. Some returns are necessary; some waiting is wise.
The marrying maiden draws out the time. She may be late in marrying. There is a time for delay. To draw out the time is not to waste it; it is to wait for the right moment. Late, but not too late.

The sovereign I gave his daughter in marriage. The embroidered garments of the princess were not as fine as those of the concubine. The moon is nearly full. Good fortune. The princess—the primary wife—is outshone by the concubine's virtue. The moon is nearly full; her influence grows. Good fortune because quality, not status, determines worth. The secondary position does not diminish true excellence.

The woman holds the basket, but there are no fruits in it. The man stabs the sheep, but no blood flows. Nothing that furthers. Empty rituals, forms without substance. The basket is held, but empty; the sheep is stabbed, but no blood flows. The union produces nothing because the heart is not in it. This is the danger of the secondary position: becoming mere form, losing substance. Do not let this happen. Even in constraint, be real.

trigrams.description: Lake below, thunder above. Thunder stirs the lake, but the lake does not rise to meet it. This is the marrying maiden: a union that is not fully reciprocal, a relationship of unequal power. The lake receives the thunder's energy but cannot return it. In such a situation, the wise one accepts the gift without demanding more, and uses what is given to grow in stillness.

taoist_reflection: The Tao Te Ching says: 'To know the masculine and keep to the feminine is to be the valley of the world.' Hexagram 54 is the feminine kept, the valley that receives without demanding. The marrying maiden, in her secondary position, can still be a valley—deep, receptive, nourishing. The thunder comes and goes; the lake remains. In the end, the valley outlasts the mountain. The one who accepts her place with grace may find that the place itself transforms.

name: Abundance (豐 - Fēng)
heart: Fire over thunder. Lightning flashes, thunder rolls—the height of power, the peak of influence. Abundance is fullness, prosperity, the moment when everything is present. But the hexagram warns: abundance does not last. The sun must set, the moon must wane. In times of abundance, the wise one does not grasp; they give. They do not cling; they share. For fullness, rightly used, becomes blessing. Hoarded, it becomes poison.

ancient.chinese: 豐。亨。王假之，勿憂，宜日中。
ancient.rendering: Abundance has success. The king attains abundance. Do not grieve. Be like the sun at midday.

judgment: Success comes with abundance, but it is not for you alone. The king attains it, but he must use it for all. Do not grieve that abundance cannot last; that is its nature. Be like the sun at midday—at its peak, it gives most light. It does not hoard its rays. In your abundance, give. In your fullness, share. The sun does not grieve that it must set; it shines fully while it can. So too, you.
image: Fire over thunder. The noble one decides lawsuits and carries out punishments. Fire over thunder: the flash reveals, the shock enforces. The noble one learns: in times of abundance, clarity and justice are possible. Decide lawsuits—bring resolution. Carry out punishments—maintain order. Abundance is not just for enjoyment; it is for right action. Use your fullness to set things right.
lines: When you meet your match, you are alike. Even if you are of no account, there is no blame. Going forward brings honor. In abundance, you meet your match—one who shares your quality. Even if you are humble, this meeting is without blame. Go forward; honor awaits.

The screen is so full of light that you see a speck. Going forward brings doubt. With goodwill and sacrifice, good fortune. So much light that it obscures; you see a speck, a flaw. Doubt arises. But with goodwill and sacrifice—with sincere offering—good fortune follows. Do not let the flaw blind you to the whole.

The underbrush is so thick that you see a small speck. Not seeing the big person. In abundance, obscurity can come from excess—too much, and you miss the essential. Not seeing the big person because the small fills your vision. The line warns: clear the underbrush.

The screen is so full of light that you see a speck. You meet the big person. Good fortune. Again the light obscures, but now you meet the big person—the one who sees through the glare. Good fortune because recognition transcends the excess.
Lines are coming. Blessing and fame draw near. Good fortune. Abundance at its peak: lines converge, blessings arrive, fame approaches. Good fortune because you are ready to receive without grasping.

His house is in a state of abundance. He screens off his family. He peers through the gate and no longer perceives anyone. For three years he sees nothing. Misfortune. Abundance misused: he screens off his family, isolates himself. Peers through the gate and sees no one. For three years, a full cycle, he sees nothing. Misfortune because abundance became a prison. Do not let your fullness separate you from others.

trigrams.description: Fire below, thunder above. Light and sound together—the peak of manifestation. Abundance is this: the full expression of power, the complete display of wealth. But the wise one knows that thunder fades and fire dims. In abundance, be generous; in fullness, be humble.

taoist_reflection: The Tao Te Ching says: 'To hold and fill to overflowing is not as good as to stop. To sharpen a blade and keep it too sharp cannot be kept long.' Hexagram 55 is the overflowing cup, the too-sharp blade. Abundance is a gift, but only if you know when to stop. The sun at midday gives most light, but it also begins its descent. The sage in abundance does not try to prolong it; they use it while it lasts, and let it go when it passes. In this, they are like the sun: full, generous, and unafraid of the setting.

name: The Wanderer (旅 - Lǚ)
heart: Fire over mountain. Fire burns on the mountain, bright but not rooted. The wanderer is one who travels, who has no fixed home. They are exposed, dependent on the hospitality of others. Yet the wanderer also sees new lands, meets new people, grows in ways the settled cannot. The hexagram counsels: be prudent, be modest, attach yourself to what is reliable, and do not stay too long. The wanderer's path is one of constant learning, constant leaving.

ancient.chinese: 旅。小亨，旅貞吉。
ancient.rendering: The Wanderer. Success in small matters. Perseverance brings good fortune to the wanderer.

judgment: The wanderer does not seek great things. Small successes are enough. Perseverance in the wandering life brings good fortune—not because you accumulate, but because you learn. In each new place, be modest. Attach yourself to what is trustworthy. Do not stay beyond your welcome. The wanderer who follows these rules will always find a place to rest. The fire on the mountain burns brightly, but it does not consume the mountain; it accepts its temporary home.
image: Fire over mountain. The noble one is clear-minded and cautious in imposing penalties. Fire over mountain: the light reveals, but the mountain remains. The noble one learns: be clear-minded—see what is. Be cautious in imposing penalties—the wanderer has no local knowledge, no deep ties. Do not judge too quickly. In a strange place, mercy is wiser than strictness.
lines: The wanderer is busy with trivial things. Thus he brings misfortune upon himself. The first mistake: fussing over small matters, losing sight of the larger context. The wanderer, anxious, busies himself with trifles and brings misfortune. Relax. See the whole.

The wanderer comes to an inn. He has his possessions with him. He wins the heart of a young servant. The inn—a temporary home. Possessions—what he carries. The servant—a local connection. Good fortune because he finds shelter and a bond. The wanderer needs both: a place to rest and someone to trust.

The wanderer's inn burns down. He loses the heart of his young servant. Danger. The inn destroyed, the bond broken. Danger because his supports are gone. The line does not offer comfort; it simply records. In wandering, losses come. The only response is to move on.

The wanderer rests in a shelter. He has his possessions with him. But my heart is not glad. A shelter, not a home. Possessions, but not peace. The heart is not glad because the wandering itself is wearying. This line acknowledges the cost of the path. Even with necessities, the soul may ache.

He shoots a pheasant. It drops with the first arrow. In the end, he gets praise and a mandate. A small success—the pheasant falls. But from this small act, he earns praise and a mandate. In wandering, small deeds can lead to recognition. Do not despise the small.

The bird's nest burns up. The wanderer first laughs, then cries. He loses his cow. Misfortune. The final loss: the nest, the home, the cow—the resource. First laughter (denial? relief?), then tears. Misfortune because everything is gone. The wanderer must now wander with nothing. Yet even this is not the end; it is the deepest teaching of impermanence.

trigrams.description: Mountain below, fire above. Fire rests on the mountain, bright but temporary. The wanderer is like this: a visitor, a guest. The mountain endures; the fire moves on. In wandering, accept that you are not the mountain. You are the fire, here today, gone tomorrow. Burn brightly while you stay.

taoist_reflection: The Tao Te Ching says: 'The good traveler leaves no tracks.' Hexagram 56 is the traveler who leaves light tracks, who does not cling, who moves through the world like fire over mountain—bright, warm, and gone. The wanderer's path is the path of non-attachment. You have no permanent home, so you are at home everywhere. You have no fixed identity, so you can become anyone. The sage wanders through life as through a foreign country—curious, humble, free. And in the end, they leave no tracks because they never claimed any ground.

name: The Gentle (巽 - Xùn)
heart: Wind over wind. Gentle, penetrating, persistent. The Gentle is the power of influence without force, of persuasion without argument. Wind does not break the tree; it bends it over time. It does not command the clouds; it moves them. In human life, the gentle approach is often the most powerful: a soft word turns away wrath, a steady presence changes hearts. The wise one does not push; they permeate.

ancient.chinese: 巽。小亨，利有攸往，利見大人。
ancient.rendering: The Gentle. Success in small matters. It furthers one to undertake something. It furthers one to see the great person.

judgment: The gentle way succeeds in small matters—the daily interactions, the subtle influences. It furthers one to undertake something, because gentle action, persistently applied, accomplishes much. It furthers to see the great person—one who embodies this gentle power, who can teach you its ways. The wind does not strive; it simply moves. In its moving, it shapes mountains. So too, your gentle persistence will shape your world.
image: Winds following one another. The noble one spreads his commands and carries out his affairs. Wind after wind: influence compounding, messages spreading. The noble one learns: spread your commands—not by shouting, but by letting them be carried. Carry out your affairs—not by forcing, but by persistent gentle action. The winds do not tire; they simply continue. So too, the noble one.
lines: Advancing and retreating. It furthers the perseverance of a warrior. The first movement of the gentle: advancing, then retreating—testing, feeling. This is not indecision; it is the warrior's reconnaissance. Perseverance in this probing furthers. Know the ground before you commit.

The gentle beneath the bed. Priests and magicians are used in great number. Good fortune. No blame. The gentle so deep it goes under the bed—into the hidden, the unconscious. Priests and magicians—ritual, tradition—are used. Good fortune because you access the depths. No blame because you use what works.

Repeatedly entering the gentle. Humiliation. To be too gentle, too yielding, too compliant—repeatedly entering the gentle—brings humiliation. The wind that always bends breaks nothing. Know when to be firm.

Regret disappears. In the hunt, you catch three kinds of game. The gentle applied with purpose: regret disappears because you act effectively. In the hunt, you catch three kinds of game—success in multiple areas. The gentle way, when rightly directed, achieves much.

Perseverance brings good fortune. Regret disappears. Nothing that does not further. No beginning, but an end. Before the change, three days. After the change, three days. Good fortune. The culmination: perseverance brings good fortune, regret dissolves, everything furthers. There is no beginning—you cannot trace the start of the gentle influence. But there is an end—a clear result. Three days before and after—the cycle of preparation and integration. Good fortune because the gentle way has become natural, effortless.

The gentle beneath the bed. He loses his possessions and his axe. Perseverance brings misfortune. Too deep, too far: under the bed, he loses his tools—his axe, his means of acting. Perseverance in this hiddenness brings misfortune. Even the gentle must sometimes emerge.

trigrams.description: Wind over wind. Influence upon influence. The Gentle is not a single breeze; it is the constant wind that shapes landscapes. It does not force; it persists. The wise one learns that the softest thing in the world can overcome the hardest, simply by continuing.

taoist_reflection: The Tao Te Ching says: 'The softest thing in the world rides over the hardest thing in the world. That which has no substance enters where there is no space.' Hexagram 57 is the softest thing made manifest. The wind cannot be grasped, yet it moves mountains. The gentle cannot be resisted, yet it changes hearts. The sage does not argue, does not fight, does not insist. They simply continue, like wind over wind, and in time, all things yield.

name: The Joyous (兌 - Duì)
heart: Lake over lake. Water reflecting water, joy upon joy. The Joyous is the power of authentic happiness—not the fleeting pleasure of acquisition, but the deep joy of connection, of presence, of being fully alive. True joy is contagious; it spreads like ripples on a lake. The wise one does not seek joy; they become a source of it, and others are refreshed.

ancient.chinese: 兌。亨，利貞。
ancient.rendering: The Joyous. Success. Perseverance furthers.

judgment: Joy succeeds because it opens hearts. When you are genuinely joyful, others are drawn to you, and together you create more joy. Perseverance in this authentic happiness furthers all things. But beware: joy can be counterfeited. Flattery, empty cheer, forced smiles—these are not the Joyous; they are its shadow. True joy is rooted in sincerity, in the deep satisfaction of being alive and connected. Cultivate that root, and the fruit will be sweet.
image: Lakes resting one on another. The noble one discusses things with friends. Lakes together: they reflect each other, deepen each other. The noble one learns: discuss things with friends. Joy is amplified in companionship. Not shallow chatter, but deep exchange—the meeting of minds and hearts. In such discussion, joy is born and nourished.
lines: Joy that is inward and quiet. Good fortune. The first joy: inward, quiet, not dependent on others. This is the root of all true happiness. Good fortune because it cannot be taken away.

Joy that is sincere. Good fortune. Regret disappears. Sincere joy, expressed genuinely, brings good fortune. Regret disappears because you are not pretending. Your joy is real, and the world receives it.

Joy that comes from outside. Misfortune. Joy dependent on externals—on praise, on possessions, on events—brings misfortune because it cannot last. When the outside changes, the joy vanishes. Do not build your happiness on sand.

Joy that is not yet decided. The boundary is in motion. There is no rest. If you are sincere, danger will leave. Joy that wavers, that cannot settle. The boundary moves; there is no rest. But if you are sincere—if you stay true to your deepest self—danger will leave. The wavering joy finds its center.

Joy in what is genuine. Danger. But perseverance in what is right brings good fortune. To find joy in what is genuine is right, but it may bring danger because the world often fears the real. Persevere in this right joy, and good fortune follows.

Joy that is seductive and leads others on. The joy that uses others, that manipulates, that seduces—this is the corruption of the Joyous. It may work for a time, but in the end, it brings misfortune. True joy never uses; it shares.

trigrams.description: Lake over lake. Joy reflecting joy. The lakes mirror each other, their depths multiplying. This is the Joyous: not a single happiness, but happiness shared, reflected, amplified. In true joy, there is no taking; there is only giving and receiving, like lakes exchanging their reflections.

taoist_reflection: The Tao Te Ching says: 'I have three treasures that I hold and keep. The first is compassion. The second is frugality. The third is not daring to be ahead of the world.' Hexagram 58 is the treasure of compassion made manifest. True joy is compassionate; it does not seek its own at the expense of others. It is frugal; it does not need excess to be happy. It does not dare to be ahead; it is content to be with. In this, it is like the lake: deep, still, reflecting all, asking nothing.

name: Dispersion (渙 - Huàn)
heart: Wind over water. Wind scatters the clouds, disperses the mist. Dispersion is the breaking up of what has become stagnant—rigid thoughts, frozen feelings, blocked energy. Not destruction, but release. The wind does not destroy the water; it moves it, clears it, refreshes it. In human life, dispersion comes when we need to let go, to forgive, to release what no longer serves. The wise one welcomes the wind that clears the heart.

ancient.chinese: 渙。亨。王假有廟，利涉大川，利貞。
ancient.rendering: Dispersion. Success. The king approaches his temple. It furthers one to cross the great water. Perseverance furthers.

judgment: Dispersion brings success because it clears the way. The king approaches his temple—the center, the sacred—after the dispersion of what distracted him. It furthers one to cross the great water—the great difficulty—because the obstacles have been scattered. Perseverance in this clearing furthers all things. Do not cling to what must disperse. Let the wind do its work, and you will find yourself lighter, clearer, ready for the crossing.
image: Wind over water. The ancient kings sacrificed to the Lord and built temples. Wind over water: the wind moves the water, clears the surface. The ancient kings learned: sacrifice to the Lord—offer thanks for the clearing. Build temples—create spaces where the sacred can be encountered. Dispersion is not just loss; it is the condition for new connection. After the scattering, gather at the temple.
lines: He brings help with strong horses. Good fortune. At the first sign of dispersion, strong horses—energy, resources—arrive to help. Good fortune because you are supported. The dispersion is not abandonment; it is redistribution.

During dispersion, he hurries to his support. Regret disappears. When the scattering begins, hurry to what supports you—friends, practice, truth. Regret disappears because you do not wait until you are scattered too far.

He disperses his own self. No regret. The deepest dispersion: letting go of the self, the ego, the fixed identity. No regret because what remains is more real than what was lost. The self was the last obstacle.

He disperses his group. Great good fortune. The group—the tribe, the identity—disperses. This seems like loss, but it is great good fortune because the group was a barrier to larger connection. After dispersion, you can belong to all.

Dispersion leads to sweaty announcements. Perseverance brings good fortune. The dispersion is so intense that it produces sweat—effort, release. Announcements—truths that must be spoken—come forth. Perseverance in this sweaty clearing brings good fortune.

He disperses the blood. Dispersing, leaving, departing—no blame. Blood—the deepest ties, the most visceral bonds. To disperse even these, to leave, to depart—no blame because some bonds must be released for life to continue. The final line acknowledges the hardest letting go.

trigrams.description: Water below, wind above. Wind over water—the surface stirs, the mist clears. Dispersion is this: the gentle force that moves what is stagnant, that breaks up what has frozen. The water does not resist; it ripples. The wind does not force; it moves. Together, they create clarity.

taoist_reflection: The Tao Te Ching says: 'To obtain, one must first give. To learn, one must first unlearn.' Hexagram 59 is the great unlearning, the great giving away. Dispersion is not loss; it is the clearing that allows new growth. The wind that scatters the clouds also reveals the sun. The sage who lets go of the self finds the true self. In dispersion, there is no blame—only the spaciousness of a heart that has released its hold.

name: Limitation (節 - Jié)
heart: Water over lake. The lake fills, but the water stops at its banks. Limitation is not deprivation; it is form. Without banks, the lake would spread and disappear. Without limits, life would dissipate. The wise one accepts limitation as the condition of all meaningful existence. Not to be constrained, but to be shaped. A river without banks is a flood; a life without limits is chaos.

ancient.chinese: 節。亨。苦節不可貞。
ancient.rendering: Limitation. Success. Bitter limitation should not be persevered in.

judgment: Limitation succeeds because it gives form to energy. The lake's banks allow it to be deep, to reflect, to sustain life. So too, your limits allow you to be present, to focus, to create. But bitter limitation—restriction that chafes, that crushes—should not be persevered in. Know the difference between the bank that holds and the bank that imprisons. The wise one accepts the first and resists the second.
image: Water over lake. The noble one creates number and measure, and examines virtue and conduct. Water over lake: the level is fixed, the measure clear. The noble one learns: create number and measure—standards, limits, forms. Examine virtue and conduct—see if they fit within the measure. Limitation is not arbitrary; it is the wisdom of appropriateness. What fits, flourishes. What does not, must change.
lines: Not going out of the door and the courtyard. No blame. The first limitation: staying home, within bounds. No blame because you are not yet ready for wider movement. Know your limits and respect them.

Not going out of the gate and the courtyard brings misfortune. The same action, but now it is too late. Staying within when you should go out brings misfortune. Limitation must be appropriate to time. The line warns: do not cling to limits that have outlived their use.

He who knows no limitation will have cause to lament. No blame. The one without limits laments—because life without form is chaos. But the line says no blame—perhaps because they did not know better. Yet the lament itself is the teacher.

Contented limitation. Good fortune. The ideal: limitation that is accepted, even embraced. Not bitter, not restrictive—contented. Good fortune because the limits fit like a well-made garment. They do not bind; they support.

Sweet limitation brings good fortune. Going forward brings esteem. Limitation that is sweet—pleasant, welcome—brings good fortune. To go forward within these sweet limits brings esteem. Others see that you have found the balance between freedom and form.

Bitter limitation. Perseverance brings misfortune. Regret disappears. The final warning: bitter limitation, if persevered in, brings misfortune. But regret disappears if you recognize it and let it go. The line offers a way out: see the bitterness, and release the limit that causes it.

trigrams.description: Lake below, water above. The lake has its banks; the water has its channel. Limitation is this: the forms that contain and direct energy. The lake does not resent its banks; they make it deep. The water does not curse its channel; it makes it flow. So too, the wise one honors the limits that give life form.

taoist_reflection: The Tao Te Ching says: 'The thirty spokes unite in one hub. It is the empty space that makes the wagon useful.' Hexagram 60 is the spokes and the hub—the limits that create the emptiness that is useful. Without spokes, no wheel. Without limits, no space. The sage does not fight limitation; they use it to create the container for what matters. The banks make the lake; the channel makes the river. Limitation is not the enemy of life; it is the midwife.

name: Inner Truth (中孚 - Zhōng Fú)
heart: Wind over lake. Wind moves, lake reflects—both responding, both true. Inner Truth is the quality of being real at the core, of having a center that cannot be shaken. The wind does not pretend to be still; the lake does not pretend to be deep. They are what they are, and in their truth, they interact harmoniously. The wise one cultivates this inner truth: a heart so sincere that it needs no defense, no pretense, no mask.

ancient.chinese: 中孚。豚魚吉，利涉大川，利貞。
ancient.rendering: Inner Truth. It brings good fortune even to pigs and fish. It furthers one to cross the great water. Perseverance furthers.

judgment: Inner truth is so powerful that it reaches even pigs and fish—the simplest, most unreflective beings. If you are truly sincere, your truth communicates itself to all, without words. It furthers one to cross the great water—the greatest difficulty—because inner truth is a boat that cannot sink. Perseverance in this sincerity furthers all things. The wind does not try to move the lake; it simply moves, and the lake responds. So too, you need only be true; the world will respond.
image: Wind over lake. The noble one discusses criminal cases in order to delay executions. Wind over lake: the wind stirs, the lake reflects. The noble one learns: in criminal cases, delay—not to avoid justice, but to ensure truth. Inner truth requires time to emerge. Rushed judgments miss it. The noble one waits, reflects, and only then decides.
lines: Being prepared brings good fortune. If there are hidden motives, it is restless. The first step: prepare. Be ready for truth to emerge. If you have hidden motives, you will be restless, and the truth will not come. Prepare by being empty, open.

A crane calling in the shade. Its young answer it. I have a good goblet. I will share it with you. The image of inner truth: the crane calls, and its young answer without seeing it. Truth communicates itself. The goblet shared is truth shared. No need for words; the heart speaks directly.

He finds a comrade. Now he beats the drum, now he stops. Now he sobs, now he sings. Inner truth in relationship: the comrade found, the rhythm of connection—drumming and stopping, sobbing and singing. The full range of true feeling, expressed without pretense. No blame.

The moon nearly full. The horses' mate is lost. No blame. The moon nearly full—truth almost complete. But the mate is lost—connection broken. Yet no blame because the truth itself is not diminished. Inner truth does not depend on others.
He possesses truth. He has no blame. Simple, direct: he possesses truth. No blame because truth needs nothing else. The line is almost redundant; it simply states what is.

Truth that crows. The cock crows, but it does not fly. Misfortune. Truth that is only noise, only display, not substance. The cock crows but cannot fly. This is not inner truth; it is its counterfeit. Misfortune because it will be found out.

trigrams.description: Lake below, wind above. The wind moves, the lake reflects—both in their true nature. Inner Truth is this: being so completely what you are that your presence communicates itself without effort. The lake does not try to reflect; it simply does. The wind does not try to move; it simply does. Be like them.

taoist_reflection: The Tao Te Ching says: 'He who knows does not speak; he who speaks does not know.' Hexagram 61 is the knowing that does not speak, the truth that communicates without words. The crane calls in the shade, and its young answer—not by sight, but by recognition. The sage, hidden, still influences all. Inner truth is not a message; it is a state of being. When you are true, the world cannot help but respond, because truth is the native language of all things.

name: Preponderance of the Small (小過 - Xiǎo Guò)
heart: Thunder over mountain. The thunder is loud, but the mountain is still—a small excess of sound over substance. Preponderance of the Small is the condition where the small outweighs the great, where details overwhelm the whole. Not a crisis, but an imbalance. The wise one in such times attends to the small, corrects the excess, and restores harmony. Do not despise small things; they can tip the scale.

ancient.chinese: 小過。亨，利貞。可小事，不可大事。飛鳥遺之音，不宜上宜下，大吉。
ancient.rendering: Preponderance of the Small. Success. Perseverance furthers. Small matters may be done; great matters should not be done. The flying bird leaves its song. It is better to descend than to ascend. Great good fortune.

judgment: In times when the small preponderates, success comes through attending to small matters. Great undertakings are not advisable; they will be thrown off by the imbalance. The flying bird leaves its song—a small thing, but it carries meaning. It is better to descend than to ascend. Stay low, stay humble, tend the details. Great good fortune follows because you do not attempt what you cannot yet sustain. The mountain does not try to be thunder; it simply rests, and the thunder passes.
image: Thunder over mountain. The noble one in his conduct is excessively humble. In mourning, he is excessively sorrowful. In his expenditures, he is excessively frugal. Thunder over mountain: a small excess of sound. The noble one learns: in conduct, be excessively humble—better too humble than too proud. In mourning, be excessively sorrowful—better to feel too much than too little. In expenditures, be excessively frugal—better to save too much than too little. When the small preponderates, lean into the small virtues. They will balance the scale.
lines: The bird meets with misfortune through flying. The bird that flies too high, that seeks the great when the small preponderates, meets misfortune. Stay low.

She passes by her ancestor and meets her ancestress. He does not reach his ruler and meets his minister. No blame. To pass by the greater and meet the lesser—this is the way of the small preponderance. No blame because it is appropriate to the time.

If you are not excessively careful, you may be attacked from behind. Danger. The small preponderance requires extra care. If you are not careful enough, danger comes. The line warns: in small matters, vigilance is protection.

No blame. He meets him without passing by. Going brings danger. One must be on guard. Do not act. Perseverance brings good fortune. Meeting without passing—finding the right balance. Going forward now brings danger; be on guard. Do not act; simply persevere in awareness. Good fortune follows.

Dense clouds, no rain from our western region. The prince shoots and hits him in the cave. The image from hexagram 9 returns: clouds gather, but no rain. The small preponderance has not yet become the great. The prince shoots and hits—a small action, precise, effective. In the cave, in hiddenness, the small act achieves what great force could not.

He passes by, does not meet. The flying bird leaves him. Misfortune. This means calamity and injury. To pass by and not meet, to fly and miss connection—this is the misfortune of the small preponderance when it is not rightly handled. The bird leaves; the song is lost. Calamity and injury follow because the small was not attended to in time.

trigrams.description: Mountain below, thunder above. Thunder over mountain—a small excess, a momentary imbalance. The mountain does not try to match the thunder; it remains still. The wise one in times of small preponderance does not attempt great things; they tend the small, correct the little imbalances, and wait for the thunder to pass.

taoist_reflection: The Tao Te Ching says: 'The heavy is the root of the light. The still is the master of the restless.' Hexagram 62 is the light and restless in excess, the heavy and still as the remedy. When the small preponderates, return to the heavy, the still, the low. Descend, do not ascend. The bird that flies too high meets misfortune; the bird that stays near the earth hears its own song. The sage in times of imbalance does not seek to dominate; they become more humble, more careful, more still. In this, they become the root that stabilizes all.

name: After Completion (既濟 - Jì Jì)
heart: Water over fire. The fire has heated the water; the water has tempered the fire. Their work is done; balance is achieved. After Completion is the moment of success, of fulfillment, of harmony. But the hexagram warns: this moment is also the beginning of decline. The fire will dim, the water will cool. After completion, the wise one does not rest on achievement; they prepare for what comes next. The crossing is complete, but the river still flows.

ancient.chinese: 既濟。亨小，利貞。初吉終亂。
ancient.rendering: After Completion. Success in small matters. Perseverance furthers. At the beginning, good fortune; at the end, disorder.

judgment: After completion, success is in small matters—maintaining, adjusting, fine-tuning. Perseverance in this careful tending furthers. At the beginning, good fortune; at the end, disorder. This is the law of all achievement: what is made will unmake; what is completed will be undone. The wise one does not despair at this; they accept it as natural. They enjoy the completion while it lasts, and they prepare for the inevitable change. The fire and water have done their work; now they rest. You too, after completion, rest—but stay awake.
image: Water over fire. The noble one takes thought of misfortune and arms himself against it in advance. Water over fire: balance achieved, but the water may quench the fire, the fire may boil the water. The noble one learns: think of misfortune. Arm against it in advance. Not from fear, but from wisdom. After completion, the seeds of disorder are already present. The wise one sees them and prepares. Not to prevent the inevitable, but to meet it with grace.
lines: He brakes his wheels. He gets his tail in the water. No blame. The first step after completion: slow down. Brake the wheels. The tail gets wet—a small consequence, not fatal. No blame because you are cautious. Completion is not a time for speed.

The woman loses her curtain. Do not go in pursuit. In seven days you will get it back. After completion, small losses occur. The curtain—privacy, modesty—is lost. Do not chase it. In seven days—a full cycle—it will return. Patience restores what is truly yours.

The high ancestor attacks the demon region. After three years, he subdues it. Inferior people should not be employed. Great tasks after completion take time—three years to subdue the demon. The warning: inferior people—those who would exploit the success—should not be employed. Completion is vulnerable to corruption. Guard it with good people.

The finest cloth may become rags. Be careful all day long. The finest things decay. Completion is not permanent. Be careful all day long—attention, not anxiety. Watch for the signs of decay, and tend them early.

The neighbor in the east who slaughters an ox does not attain as much blessing as the neighbor in the west with his small offering. In after completion, small sincerity outdoes large ritual. The east slaughters an ox—great sacrifice, but perhaps performed without heart. The west offers a small gift, but with true feeling. He attains blessing. After completion, quality matters more than quantity.

He gets his head in the water. Danger. The final immersion: head in water, the completion overwhelmed. Danger because the balance is lost. The line does not offer hope; it simply records. After completion, there is also after. The cycle continues.

trigrams.description: Fire below, water above. The water and fire have found balance—neither overcomes the other. This is after completion: the moment of perfect harmony. But the hexagram's position—63 of 64—reminds us that after completion comes dissolution. The fire will dim, the water will cool. Enjoy the harmony, but do not cling.

taoist_reflection: The Tao Te Ching says: 'The Tao that can be told is not the eternal Tao. The name that can be named is not the eternal name.' Hexagram 63 is the completion that can be completed—and therefore, it is not eternal. After completion, there is always another hexagram. The sage does not seek permanent success; they seek right action in each moment. The fire and water will separate; that is their nature. But for now, they are in balance. Be grateful, be careful, and let the next moment come.

name: Before Completion (未濟 - Wèi Jì)
heart: Fire over water. The fire rises, the water sinks—they move apart, not yet in harmony. Before Completion is the final hexagram, the last of sixty-four, yet it points forward. Nothing is ever truly finished. After every completion, there is a new beginning. The young fox has almost crossed the stream, but its tail gets wet. Almost, but not yet. This is the human condition: always approaching, never fully arriving. And this is not failure; it is the way.

ancient.chinese: 未濟。亨。小狐汔濟，濡其尾，无攸利。
ancient.rendering: Before Completion. Success. But the little fox, after almost crossing, gets its tail wet. Nothing that would further.

judgment: Before completion, success is still possible—but not yet. The little fox almost crosses, then wets its tail. The crossing is not complete. Nothing furthers at this moment because the time is not ripe. Yet this hexagram is not despair; it is the most hopeful of all. It is the last, but it points to the first. After 63, before 64, the cycle begins again. The fire and water are separate, but they will meet. The fox will cross. Not now, but soon. Persevere in the approach; the completion will come.
image: Fire over water. The noble one is careful in distinguishing things and giving them their places. Fire over water: they are separate, not yet in relation. The noble one learns: be careful in distinguishing things. Give them their places. Not yet union, but preparation. Know what each thing is, where it belongs, and the conditions for their meeting. Before completion, clarity is the foundation. When the time comes, you will be ready.
lines: He gets his tail wet. Humiliation. The first step, and already a mishap—the tail wet. Humiliation because the crossing is not yet successful. But it is only the tail; the fox itself is not submerged. A small failure, a lesson.

He brakes his wheels. Perseverance brings good fortune. After the wet tail, slow down. Brake the wheels. Perseverance in this caution brings good fortune. The crossing can wait; better to arrive late than not at all.

Before completion, setting forth brings misfortune. It furthers one to cross the great water. The warning: setting forth now, in haste, brings misfortune. Yet it furthers to cross the great water—the great task—but only when the time is right. Discernment is all.

Perseverance brings good fortune. Regret disappears. Shock, thus to discipline the kingdom. For three years, invest in great regions. After the caution, after the waiting, perseverance brings good fortune. Regret disappears. Now use the shock—the energy—to discipline the kingdom, to invest in great regions. The time for action approaches.

Perseverance brings good fortune. No regret. The light of the noble one is true. Good fortune. At the threshold: perseverance still brings good fortune, now without regret. The noble one's light is true—clear, steady. Good fortune because you are ready.

He drinks wine. No blame. But if he gets his head wet, he loses it, in truth. The final line: at the very end, you may relax—drink wine. No blame in that. But if you get your head wet—if you go too far, lose yourself—you lose it, in truth. Before completion, even at the last step, stay aware. The crossing is almost done, but not yet. Do not drown at the shore.

trigrams.description: Water below, fire above. They move apart, not yet in harmony. Before Completion is the state of potential, of approaching, of almost. The fire and water will meet—they always do. But not yet. The wise one in this state waits, prepares, and trusts the process. The crossing will be made. The cycle will continue.

taoist_reflection: The Tao Te Ching says: 'The Tao is hidden and nameless. Yet it alone nourishes and completes all things.' Hexagram 64 is the hidden Tao, the completion that is not yet complete, the name that cannot be named. After sixty-three stages, we return to the beginning. The fox almost crosses; the cycle almost ends. But there is no end. The Tao flows on, eternally before completion, eternally approaching. The wise one does not demand arrival; they find peace in the approach, joy in the almost. The tail is wet, but the crossing continues. And that is enough.
